content.description:
On the left of the figure is a 12 inch by 12 inch square with both vertical and horizontal dashed lines set x inches in from each side of the square. For this square:

The dashed lines intersect to form an x inch by x inch square at each of the four corners of the original square.

The smaller x inch by x inch squares are shaded.

On the right of the figure is an open box with no top. For this box:

The box is created by removing the x inch by x inch squares from the original square and folding up the resulting sides.

The box is labeled with a height of x.

The figure shows a square sheet of cardboard on the left and an open box on the right. The square sheet has side length <math alttext="12"> <mn>12</mn> </math> inches (in) and is used to make the open box by removing from each of the four corners a square of side length <math alttext="x"><mi>x</mi></math> inches, and folding up the sides.
content.question: For what value of <math alttext="x"> <mi>x</mi> </math> does the box have the maximum possible volume? Note: The volume of a rectangular solid with length <math alttext="l"><mi>l</mi></math>, width <math alttext="w"><mi>w</mi></math>, and height <math alttext="h"><mi>h</mi></math> is <math alttext="V equals l w h"> <mi>V</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mi>l</mi> <mi>w</mi> <mi>h</mi> </math>.
